An Interview with James T. Farrell
Dialectical Configurations in Juno and the Paycock
Humbert Humbert Through the Looking Glass

artinfo.ab: Carroll's strong influence on Nabokov can be seen through an application of +Through the Looking Glass= to +Lolita.= In addition to the "wonderland" motif, similarities in theme, language, and plot occur. Time and space move backwards, themes of the mirage and double appear, language fractures nonsensically, and plot parallels abound. Also, in this context, two levels of the novel emerge. The first shows Humbert's attempt to break through mirrored reality and his final success at Quilty's murder, the second, Humbert's prison narration from the perspective of the other side of the looking glass. That each ends in entrapment supports Nabokov's distinction between imaginative windows which provide release from time and self, and mirrors which imprison. The two works juxtaposed, then, reinforce Humbert's captivity, at the same time illustrating Nabokov's theory that the imprisoning world of mirrors is also a realm of esthetic delight.

tig.atl: Lolita and the Dangers of Fiction

artinfo.ab: Nabokov's +Lolita= plays with the relations between a work of art, the experiences that underlie it, and the effects it may have upon its readers. Humbert Humbert attempts to transcend time by perceiving his life in literary terms and by imposing on Dolores Haze and stability of a literary character whom he names Lolita. He succeeds by memorializing their past and thereby making them immortal. His greatness as a writer lies in his "fixing" Lolita as a character, but the identical process in his life constitutes his worst crime. By addressing his audience both as reader and as judge and jury, Humbert calls on us to balance his artistic creation against his life. He also compels us to share his position: our reading enables Humbert and his nymphet to exist beyond death, but only as unchangeable literary characters.

tig.atl: Ionesco: Anything but Absurd

artinfo.ab: Most criticism of Ionesco explores his supposedly "negative" philosophy, rather than his positive artistic achievements. In his early short plays he displays a simultaneous mastery over the apparently opposed genres of tragedy and farce. +The Chairs= consists of a character study blurred by dreamlike, farcical circumstances that have a tragic outcome, a suicide. The character studies is the Old Man, of whose personality the other two characters (his wife and the Orator) are satirized aspects, his base and higher selves, as he perceives them. The play's action unfolds the Old Man's life at the moment just before his death, and also represents a conflict in the one figure between a social adult and a preliterate child, dramatized by his nonsense talk. The stage's semicircular cyclorama, which becomes crammed with invisible guests on chairs implies (subtends) as its missing half the auditorium, where the all-too-visable audience sits.

tig.atl: A Psychronology of Lust in the Menippean Tradition: Giles Goat-Boy

artinfo.ab: As an allegory of the psychological and social schisms experienced by modern man, Barth's +Giles Goat-Boy= uses Menippean satire conventions to establish its controlling norms. A primary cause of modern disorder, the allegory argues, is the deracination of the rational-analytical part of man's soul from its ground in natural feelings and holistic intuition. The protagonist George Giles is faced with the task of putting the individual and corporate soul together again by learning, through experience often tragic, to mediate between the analytical mode of knowing, symbolized by WESCAC, and the intuitive mode, embodied in the archetypal feminine, Anastasia. Typical of Menippean satires, +Giles Goat-Boy= employs extravagant parody of the literary tradition to revitalize the imagination of its readers. The satire includes in its vision the extreme limits of experience-from physical to intellectual, farcical to serious, obscene to sacred, comic to tragic-illustrating that a +via media,= encompassing the earth and the transcendent, is the way to order in the imagination.

tig.atl: American Literature as Black Mass: Edward Dahlberg

artinfo.ab: Although Dahlberg has generally thought of himself as an Ishmael figure in a decadent America, he has rejected expatriation. Supposing "everything American" to be in his "marrow," he has vigorously censured those authors who seem to him to have converted the national literature into a "humbug Black Mass." Utilizing various critical modes he has charged the literary celebrants of this Mass variously with slaying their mother-tongue, with diabolism and primitivism, with misanthropy and moral ambiguity, and with an insensitivity to the "seminal logoi" and the vibrant "pulse" of life and the "carnal heart." in contrast he has found redemptive exemplars in Thoreau, Anderson, Whitman, and Dreiser, whose composite utterance affirms the values of a rapport with the native earth, of the old agrarian virtues and manners, and of individualistic integrity.

tig.atl: The Metamorphoses of Edith Wharton in Henry James's The Finer Grain

artinfo.ab: The stories in +The Finer Grain= are fictional analogues of the complex feelings characterizing the friendship between James and Wharton, and may be called a Wharton suite, since James's précis for the dust-jacket of the book tells how the hero of "finer grain" in each tale comes into conflict with the woman who goes against his grain. Each story fictionalizes a different aspect of Wharton. In "The Velvet Glove" she is seen as a scribbling princess who begs for a literary puff; in "Mora Montravers" she is "the new woman" who embarks on her own career and defies conventions; in "A Round of Visits" she is a returned expatriate who is getting a divorce; and in the last tale, "The Bench of Desolation," she turns from a blackmailing woman into a fairy godmother offering handfuls of money to the hero who has gone systematically downhill from story to story. Wharton seems to have responded by "fictionalizing" James in "The Eyes" written right after +The Finer Grain= stories.

tig.atl: The Eighth Day of Creation: William Carlos Williams' Late Poems
The Interlace Element in Paterson

artinfo.ab: The Unicorn tapestries, which contribute to the subject matter of Book V of Williams' +Paterson,= also provide an analogy for understanding Williams' arrangement of the poem's materials. The weavers' interlacing of colored threads to form a design is analogous to the ways in which Williams develops his themes by the interlacing and juxtaposing of events, images, and phrases. There are two kinds of interlace in +Paterson.= The first is the interweaving of originally or logically continuous, or of basically homogeneous, material. The second type of interlace is a continual process of cross-referencing, based primarily on a number of narrative sequences, events, or images, initially related in full, elements of which are later used to amplify and illuminate other aspects of the poem.

tig.atl: The Quest for Pynchon

artinfo.ab: "The Quest for Pynchon" presents the most complete biography of Pynchon to date, summarizes his previously unnoticed short story "The Small Rain," and describes some of the relevant and/or interesting details of the Pynchon family history back to the Norman Conquest. The moral and practical dilemmas of studying an author averse to such investigation are explored.

tig.atl: Criticism in New Composition: Ulysses and The Sound and the Fury

artinfo.ab: Although Faulkner denied it, he apparently knew +Ulysses= well, and the Joycean interior monologue improved his characterization techniques. In Quentin's section, Faulkner combines stream-of-consciousness methods with first person narration, employing Joyce's combination of external description and direct internal report and contrasting controlled and uncontrolled thoughts. Structurally, Quentin's section resembles Bloom's day; both characters react to the passing day. External events counterpoint the characters' minds, and Faulkner uses Joycean techniques to depict Quentin's deteriorating relationship to the outside world. Joyce's characters think of the past but live primarily in the present; Quentin is engulfed by the past. Faulkner also uses Joycean techniques in Benjy's section, but the last two parts contain none. Faulkner merges the stream-of-consciousness method with more traditional story-telling techniques, making possible his later achievements in omniscient narration.

tig.atl: The Liberal Novelist in the McCarthy Era
Selected Articles on Thomas Pynchon: An Annotated Bibliography
Pynchon's Poetry

artinfo.ab: From the first paragraph of his first novel to the last paragraph of his latest one, poems, and particularly songs, make up a characteristic part of Pynchon's work. The songs work to create and conceal the author's identity as well as to provide flexibility of treatment for his "serious" material. His poetic technique might be called "mock-democratic:" he uses an out-of-date popular style felt to be dead or specious to express a living, contemporaneous content, allowing us to re-enjoy the manner without feeling cheated by the author's asking us to believe in it, to take it seriously, except as ironic implication. A change in this technique at the end of +Gravity's Rainbow= seems to signal a new point of departure or terminus in Pynchon's art.

tig.atl: The Calculus of Transformation: More Mathematical Imagery in Gravity's Rainbow

artinfo.ab: Study of mathematical references in +Gravity's Rainbow= reveals a pattern of imagery which delineates and affirms the possibility of personal freedom within the novel's deterministic world through a spontaneous moment of transformation. The t, associated with events in the lives of Leni Pökler and Tyrone Slothrop, symbolizes a moment of personal commitment transcending the world of cause-and-effect. The double integral, associated with the Rocket and its parabolic path, suggests transformations of life into death, time into eternity, and an old order into a new one. The singular point (or singularity) complements the significance of the first two concepts as an actual but timeless point between two states of Being. A masterful series of images, culminating in "the last delta-t" above the Orpheus Theatre, combines the mathematical references to create a moment of transformation and transcendence at the end of the novel.

tig.atl: Pynchon's Paranoid History

artinfo.ab: Focusing upon +Gravity's Rainbow,= with briefer references to +v.= and +The Crying of Lot 49,= Sanders shows that the world-view implicit in Pynchon's fiction is paranoid. Defined by quotation from Hofstadter's +The Paranoid Style in American Politics,= such a world-view represents the individual as victim of a cosmic plot, helplessly manipulated by external forces which betray their existence through myriad clues. In +Gravity's Rainbow= suspected plots include industrial cartels, wartime espionage, black markets, and psychological experiments. The central plot is that of matter itself, expressed through gravity and the laws of thermodynamics, leading entropically toward cosmic annihilation. Point for point, this world-view is analogous to that elaborated within Calvinism and Puritanism. Pynchon's paranoid style appears to be a secular version of these religious ideologies. His paranoid world-view, finally, reflects our experience of anomie and fragmentation in advanced industrial society.

tig.atl: Pentecost, Promiscuity, and Pynchon's V.: From the Scaffold to the Impulsive

artinfo.ab: Pynchon's vision disturbs readers because he not only dramatizes but also welcomes an entropic world. Why? In +V.= and his subsequent novels he increasingly suggests that beyond the end is a world of tongues and promiscuity - a Pentecostal world. The state of Pentecost is like entropy but with the value of total, immediate, and indiscrete communication added. Curiously, in +V.= Pynchon never mentions entropy. But he repeatedly refers to languages and argots of some twenty sorts, tongues, and Pentecost. The modes of language are clearly one of his primary topics and he often adopts a tongued style to oppose the edificial syntax of bureaucrats. If tongues is the language of Apocalypse, then Pynchon's style and structure are apocalyptic without regret. This unabashed but cagey preference for apparent disorder is basic to Pynchon's rebuke of modernism. Pynchon's news in noise, his communication in chaos, establishes his post-modernism.

tig.atl: Essays on Thomas Pynchon
The Importance of Thomas Pynchon
The Sursymamericubealism of Gertrude Stein

artinfo.ab: In isolating the threads of influence on Stein's imagination, correlating her uses of language with uses found in Emerson, William James, Henry Adams and connecting her interests with definable American doctrine and ideology we discover reasons why like doctrines derived from European sources were synthesized in her +oeuvre.= The reach and shape of modernist art, therefore, are more vividly seen and more thoroughly perceived by way of a close study of Stein's career than other studies of other figures - more accomplished and influential - have contrived to exhibit.

tig.atl: Was There an English Surrealist Group in the Forties? Two Unpublished Letters
View from the White Cliffs: A Close Look at One Manifestation of English Surrealism

artinfo.ab: Many poetic manifestations of Surrealism in England in the 1930s are different in degree from French Surrealist poetry. This contention is based on the relegation of the surrealist technique of "psychic automatism" ("automatic writing") to secondary concern in the +Second Manifesto= period and immediately after, which resulted in a more conscious use than hitherto of spontaneuosly-generated material. A close look at Gascoyne's poem "The Diabolical Principle" is illustrative of the conscious use and shaping of surrealist imagery. Poets usually gained rather than lost by tampering with the spontaneous impulse, achieving the dramatic "crisis in consciousness" without totally sacrificing coherency. The conscious manipulation of material on the surrealist poet's part makes practical analysis of the text not only feasible but frequently rewarding.

tig.atl: Dali's Paranoia-Criticism, or the Exercise of Freedom
From Poisson soluble to Constellations: Breton's Trajectory for Surrealism

artinfo.ab: The juxtaposition of Breton's last poetic work, +Constellations=, with the theories of automatic writing exposed in the First Manifesto reveals a striking departure from his early, spontaneous expression of surrealist language to the tightly woven, elliptical patterns of the enigmatic verbal tapestries written as "prose parallels" to Miro's 22 gouaches. In +Constellations= Breton identifies the poet as weaver, magician, and wanderer, closely involved with the movements of the universe. He makes use of human, animal, plant, and mineral metaphors, and catalytic fire, to show interconnections and communion in the metamorphic processes of the natural world. From +Poisson soluble=, his first automatic prose, to +Constellations=, Breton progresses to a very structured form combining the powers of poetic craft with those objective chance: "adresse et hasard." In adopting a style reminiscent of Mallarmé's last phase, he retains, however, his affirmative philosophy.

tig.atl: Surrealism: The Language of the Unthought

artinfo.ab: Breton acknowledged Surrealism's debt to Magritte because the painter ignored conventional concepts of reality and made forms latent within the objects surrounding us visible, thus expressing the unthought, the paradoxical matrix of existence. Such writers as Kafka, Sartre, and Beckett have used a comparable language to "eff the ineffable." Not unlike Magritte's feet and shoes in "The Red Model," the Castle and its official Klamm fuse surrealistically in Kafka's +The Castle=. The Roquentin of Sartre's +La Nausée= gains philosophical insights through the surrealistic transformation of his world, as the names society has assigned to objects detach themselves from them. In Beckett's +Watt=, relationships between objects and people are as dynamically ambivalent and fluctuating as they are in Magritte's "False Mirror" whose huge eye stares at us while we seemingly look at it. Like the Belgian painter, these writers use the language of paradox and the unthought to reveal the fullness of existence.

tig.atl: The Poetics of a Surrealist Passage and Beyond

artinfo.ab: A discussion of Breton's vocabulary of +attente= and +appel= in a passage from +Fata Morgana= leads to the ideas of passage itself, and of passing, illustrated by "Le Passage de l'Opéra," linguistically by the wordplay in a poem from +L'Air de l'eau=, and thematically by char's passage by burning from +Arsenal= and +Artine=, both texts of arson, to +La Nuit talismanique=, still guided by one illuminating image. In La tour's paintings, the fingers lit by the candle flame at their center and reminiscent of the burned fingers in the First Surrealist Manifesto have their own passage toward Char's own "Madeleine à la veilleuse," toward the "other hand" holding the candle in that talismanic night, and in the constellation of +Aromates chasseurs=, the final and celestial passage from the verbal archipelago of his poetry.

tig.atl: Simultaneity: Driving Force of the Surrealist Aesthetic

artinfo.ab: The various phases of the surrealist adventure-the theoretical side and the +travaux pratiques=-lean heavily on the notion, or phenomenon, of simultaneity. Breton and the surrealists use various means to liberate man from the prison of his organic self all make much of the Rimbaldian alchemy of the Word an Heraclitean mysticism or actually use duality and simultaneity in their works: binary poetic images, puns, spatial simultaneity, syntactical ambiguity, and the like.

tig.atl: Essays on Surrealism
Fifty Years Later: The Manifesto of Surrealism

artinfo.ab: It is in the language of dreams-that of desire seeking satisfaction-that Breton speaks most directly in his +Manifeste du Surréalisme=, both to those already dedicated to surrealism and to those whom his monolog in manifesto form is able to draw into fruitful unscripted dialog. The full flowering of surrealism is not to be sought in a statement like the +Manifesto of Surrealism=, but in the response it solicits.

tig.atl: Myth and Animism in Why Are We in Vietnam?
The Malign Deity of The Naked and the Dead

artinfo.ab: The island of Anopopei in Mailer's +The Naked and the Dead= is the mysterious world in which men live, a world working in unfathomable ways to confuse, terrify, and destroy them. The action and dialogue as well as the setting and atmosphere suggest the presence of a malign supernatural power which is unconcerned with the personalities and fates of individual men and reduces them to the point where they cease to be individuals. The climb up the mountain and the long haul of carrying the wounded Wilson bring to the men an epiphany in which they attain a fleeting vision of a cruelly indifferent deity. The experience in which Ridges and Goldstein had their protective illusions stripped from them and were left "naked," exposed to the numbness of despair, colors their whole future view of life.

tig.atl: Anaïs Nin: An Interview
Writing a First Novel
Edward Lewis Wallant as Urban Novelist
Thirties Fiction: A View from the '70s
The Apprenticeship of Delmore Schwartz
The 'I' in Beckett's Not I

artinfo.ab: +Not= I is Beckett's drama about an elusive pronoun. Mouth insists that the tale it tells is about "she," not "I," hence giving the title of the play. +Not= I is also "not aye," what Beckett calls elsewhere "the screaming silence of no's knife in a yes's wound." +Not= I, co-starring Auditor as ear, is also "about" Mouth, not eye. If we consider the pronoun in the title as Roman numeral, we see that the visual images exposed before us on stage are not I, but II. +Not= I yields the Jungian theory of the process of "individuation" necessary for the development of the ego.

tig.atl: Manifestations of Eros and Thanatos in L'Etranger

artinfo.ab: Thanatos structures +L'Etranger=: death of Mother, of the Other (the Arab), of the Self. These deaths are the only events which stimulate to lyrical life the neutral discourse of Meursault, walking embodiment of the death-wish, who reacts to life on the contrary with insensitivity and the indifference (primacy of the inanimate). The principal of Eros is also given a significant role: in the relationships with the Mother (first love-object), with the Other (Marie), and with the Self (imaged in Nature, as opposed to Society, and in the narcissistic discourse of the +parole vide=). Furthermore, overt manifestations of Thanatos involve covert manifestations of Eros, a notable example being the killing of the Arab, surrogate Other violated together with the virgin silence of the sunlit beach.

tig.atl: Apollinaire's Male Heroine

artinfo.ab: +The Breasts of Tiresias= by Guillaume Apollinaire consist of 16 loosely related scenes (an epic structure) and works by a series of theatrical transformations or miracles: the heroine Thérèse turns into a hero named Tiresias; her husband into a mother; objects such as a newsstand are animated, if not personified; and characters who are shot and killed instantly revive. Apollinaire also uses the assumed identity of his heroine-hero in order to mock the myth of Tiresias, that inhumane-seeming seer who has no stake in the life around him, by means of critical, political, and sexual comedy.

tig.atl: Auden, Hopkins, and the Poetry of Reticence

artinfo.ab: Auden believed that an artist could and should be reticent about intimate concerns. For him the most intimate concerns were sexual and religious. He was disturbed by Hopkins' tendency to display his personal feelings, especially his religious feelings. But revealing verse, came to understand the difficulty of the Victorian poet's isolated life and the psychological necessity for his expressing private emotions in poetry. Nevertheless, Auden masked his own emotions, and he wanted none of his intimate letters to be published and no life of himself to be written.

tig.atl: Neo-HooDoo: The Experimental Fiction of Ishmael Reed

artinfo.ab: Reed's experimental fiction breaks from the tradition of the "Neo-Slave Narrative" in Afro-American literature. Reed approaches his writing from the same metafictive angle that many modern Anglo-American writers take, but he has nonetheless striven to avoid their negative tone and philosophical despair. He has created an eclectic mythology, Neo-HooDoo, and through its values attempted a radical revaluation of black writing in the United States. But the satiric direction of his fiction is not always in harmony with Reed's mythologizing, and the result is a series of formal and thematic problems in his fiction.

tig.atl: The Dragon and the Duel: A Defense of Pound's Canto 88

artinfo.ab: Examines Pound's Canto 88 in the light of the work of Thomas Hart Benton, showing how Pound adhered closely to Benton's thought and writings. Pound's poetic enactment reveals not only a respect for historical integrity as viewed through one man's eyes, but a poet's eye for history, in which the forces of good, however defined, are ever challenged by the forces of disruption.

tig.atl: The Virgin in the Bell Biography
Unity of Archetype, Myth, and Religious Imagery in the Work of Yeats

artinfo.ab: A single mythic pattern pervades Yeats's work, the quest for or the achievement of union between man and God. Although this pattern occurs in the poems, plays, and prose in numerous versions, almost all of them can be seen as variants of the universal "monomyth," the archetypal journey motif.

tig.atl: The Unpublished Stories: Fitzgerald in His Final Stage

artinfo.ab: Fitzgerald's unpublished stories reveal much about his artistic and emotional struggles in his last years. They show him reaching for new rhetoric, plots, and characters to replace the outworn techniques of his early years as a writer. The unpublished stories are transitional, standing between the full-blown romantic pieces of the 1920s and the brief, elliptical efforts of his last two or three years. His middle-period stories deal with themes he had treated earlier, but rhetoric, characterization, plots-particularly endings-are weak and melodramatic.

tig.atl: Additions to Anthony Burgess: A Checklist (1956-1971)
Rejection of the Feminine in Carson McCullers' The Ballad of the Sad Café

artinfo.su: The Ballad of the Sad Café (1951)

tig.atl: Tragedy and Melodrama in The Confessions of Nat Turner

artinfo.ab: William Styron's Nat Turner is haunted by a post-Romantic tragic vision of life as irrational, contradictory, and terrifying. To overcome his fear, he creates simplified melodramas out of the stereotypes his culture provides. Nat's first, pastoral images of benevolent, morally pure white masters vs. filthy, animalistic black slaves are broken by repeated instances of the masters' animality and weakness. So, Nat inverts the pattern into a conflict between black messiah and depraved master. When this melodrama collapses, Nat is able to accept a religious faith that transcends both his tragic vision and his melodramatic defenses.

tig.atl: Katherine Mansfield's Journal
The Survivors: Into the Twentieth Century
The Influence of Eastern Philosophy on Yeats's Later Poetry
Ernest Hemingway's The Things That I Know

artinfo.su: Across the River and into the Trees (1950)

tig.atl: The Power of the Rap: The Black Idiom and the New Black Poetry
'It Was All Yossarian's Fault': Power and Responsibility in Catch-22
Spindrift and the Sea: Structural Patterns and Unifying Elements in Catch 22
Philip Roth: 'Old Jacob's Eye' with a Squint
God the Father and Motherless Children: Light in August
Anthony Burgess: A Checklist (1956-1971)
Riddles in Finnegans Wake
Wallace Stevens' Neglected Fugue: 'Variations on a Summer Day'
Toward 'Thingness': Cézanne's Painting and Lawrence's Poetry
Lost in the Funhouse: Barth's Use of the Recent Past
Vladimir Nabokov's Invitation to a Beheading and Robert Heinlein's 'They'
The Magus: A Study in the Creation of a Personal Myth
The American Schlemiel Abroad: Malamud's Italian Stories and the End of American Innocence
A Nelson Algren Checklist
Ethnicity in The Great Gatsby
A Case of Slightly Mistaken Identity: Gustav Mahler and Gustav Aschenbach
The Maladroit, the Medico, and the Magician: Saul Bellow's Seize the Day
Edith Wharton's War Novels: A Reappraisal
The Last Victorian Novel: Technique and Theme in Parade's End
Self-Destructive Evil in Sanctuary
Wallace Stevens and the Necessary Reader: A Technique of Dynamism
One Critical Approach to Mr. Sammler's Planet

artinfo.ab: +Mr. Sammler's Planet= constitutes some kind of perceptual 'leap' from the previous fiction published by Saul Bellow, and this leap seems to be a shift from ethical to religious faith and a return to myth from the ironic. This 'leap' can be observed textually by comparing +SP= with +Herzog=. Herzog is concerned with acquiring ethical faith; Sammler is obsessed with the quest for religious faith. +Herzog= seems a culmination of Bellow's basic themes, characters, and preoccupations; +SP=, on the other hand, employs sardonic humor. Sardonic humor is defined as a specific type of self-parody which is directed against the author's past work within the author's current, or latest work. Sammler the Younger is also a brilliantly conceived sardonic parody of Herzog. Having established that a shift in perspective has indeed taken place, the article then briefly discusses +SP= as a possible return to myth in the form of oracular revelation of Logos, and Bellow's seeming concern with religious faith.

tig.atl: Sexuality and Identity in Fortune and Men's Eyes
Kafka's Parable 'Der Kreisel': Structure and Theme

artinfo.ab: A structural analysis of Kafka's 'Der Kreisel' reveals a close harmony between structure and theme, the relationship of smallness to bigness-thus ultimately the function of the genre, parable. The analysis uses sentences and sentence-groups as well as an identification between the rectilinear form of the printed parable with its complementary balances of either side of the center-point, and the circular dimension of the top as it executes the movements described in the parable. Marxist criticism has emphasized Kafka's presumed failure to effect the dynamism implicit in his material. Such criticism would have us, in effect, attain the unattainable by changing our perspective, our view of the structure of 'Der Kreisel.' But Kafka's expressed concern is relative size, not the question of dynamism versus rest. And the nature of the structure of the parable, in such close harmony with the theme, does not lend itself to a revision of perspective. If we are left with a paradox that is, after all, the basis of parable.

tig.atl: Iris Murdoch's Midsummer Nightmare
Revolution and the Ancient Literature of Mexico, for D. H. Lawrence and Antonin Artaud

artinfo.ab: Lawrence visited Mexico in the 1920's, Artaud in the 1930's. They concurred in finding the Revolution there lacking as the 'Indian' spirit of the country had not been awakened. As a result they both familiarized themselves with the ancient Mexican scholarship of the day. In +The Plumed Serpent= Lawrence reverts to a reactionary position by making script (written by ancient Mexicans) the regulator of his projected revival. By contrast, Artaud struggles always to 'unwrite' the 'authorities' he has read and to initiate a living theater. Both their efforts were paradoxical.

tig.atl: The Artist as Narrator in The Alexandria Quartet

artinfo.ab: Throughout Durrell's +The Alexandria Quartet=, Darley embodies in his narrative method the various stages of his own artistic growth. In +Justine= he sets out to codify and recapture the four-dimensional reality of the past by inappropriately using the subjective method. With the Interlinear in +Balthazar=, Darley gains a new interpretation of the past. As he re-works his story, he moves toward a more objective method, experimenting with third-person narration and emphasizing external events. The shift from subjective to objective focus culminates in +Mountolive= where Darley becomes the omniscient narrator. He now focuses on the political lives of his characters to complete his three-sided view of the past. Returning to the first-person method in +Clea= and focusing on present experiences, Darley sees that his attempts to codify the past in the earlier novels yielded a partial truth. His last novel stresses the mythic and archetypic implications which lie beyond relative fact.

tig.atl: The Onion Eaters and the Rhetoric of Donleavy's Comedy
Césaire's Native Land and the Third World

artinfo.su: Le Cahier d'un retour au pays natal (1947)
Notebook of a Return to My Native Land

tig.atl: Jerzy Kosinski: Retreat from Violence
O'Neill and the Racial Myths

artinfo.ab: In his 'negro plays,' written from 1914 to 1924, and in +The Iceman Cometh= (1946) O'Neill moves gradually from a crude stereotype of the black man (in +Thirst=) to the perception of blackness as part of the humanity of black people. To perceive this development, one must look closely at the disputed ending of +All God's Chillun Got Wings=. Critics who read this play as only a tragedy of marriage are inevitably disappointed with its ending; but the play is simultaneously a tragic story of a marriage perverted by destiny and a representation of American race relations-as the evident symbolism helps to show-and its ending means that white America is so sick that its happiness can only be purchased through black submission to the racial myths. The plays between +Thirst= and +All God's Chillun= are ambiguous: one cannot tell whether they treat of the primitive elements in everyman or merely restate a myth about blacks; with each successive play, however, the latter possibility grows less likely. +The Iceman= is a landmark in American drama because its one black character is granted (in John Lovell's words) 'equality of struggle, aspiration, and failure.'

tig.atl: The External and Internal in Murphy
Musical Form and Principles in the Scheme of Ulysses

artinfo.ab: Musical form and principles provide an enlightening analogy for analyzing the structure and vision of Joyce's +Ulysses=. Seen as sonata form, the structure yields these divisions: chapters i-vi, statement of themes (wandering and return, usurpation, father-son relation); vii-xv, development; xvi-xvii, bridge and recapitulation; xviii, coda. The formulae of events reflect a musical conception of reality and may be related to the major themes: succession = melody (wandering and return); simultaneousness = harmony (usurpation); recurrence = rhythm (father-son relation). But Stephen perceives only discordant forces engaged in endless and meaningless transmutation of matter; like music conceived abstractly as pure mechanism, the scheme of things seems constraining and uncompromising. Bloom is no more pleased than Stephen with the unholy harmony of things, but love, analogous to the miracle of the octave, enables his adjustment. Molly, who rejects Stephen and Bloom's nice discriminations, is the home key from which Bloom strays but to which he returns. Stephen's fate seems evident in Bloom's and in Joyce's: some Molly or Nora is to become his center, from which he may stray but to which love will compel his return. In the coda the two subjects with their common themes unite and resolve in relation to Molly, as they fuse in her imagination.

tig.atl: Zeno's Ontological Confessions

artinfo.ab: Although the confessions of Italo Svevo's fictional character Zeno Cosini are written as part of the process of the character's psychoanalysis, Zeno's underlying problem is not one of psychology but rather of metaphysics. The very structure of the confessions reveals the protagonist's search for order and meaning, first in externals-the death of his father, religion, other people, women, and even time. But by the time he has begun writing the confessions, Zeno has turned to the self for this sense of order and continuity-in his smoking and in his self-conscious concern for his health. When the War interrupts, Zeno comes to realize that the pattern of all present moments can be viewed only at the end point-death. He has skirted the issue of death throughout the confessions; in the final vision he realizes that the only way back to wholeness and health may be death. And it is in this final vision that Zeno reveals that his problem is not an oedipal complex or any other psychological problem: 'We need something more than psychoanalysis to help us.'

tig.atl: Donald Barthelme's City: A Guide

artinfo.ab: Many of Donald Barthelme's short stories explore the impact of the mass media on the consciousness of the individual, showing him so bombarded by sensations and happenings that he can no longer distinguish self from surroundings. An analysis of some of Barthelme's stories suggests that not only has the distinction between the inner and outer life disappeared but that the inner life is sustained by nothing more than undifferentiated fragments of a media oriented culture which by treating wisdom and trivia on the same slightly shrill level reduces all life to a series of equally meaningless 'nownesses.' In such a culture the individual can know only the sequential or spatial ordering of events and objects, but can never approach meaning. His only refuge from the 'now' lies in meaningless abstractions, fragments of technology or past cultures. 'Truth demands an identity of essence and phenomenon,' one of Barthelme's narrators writes. But in the world of Barthelme's stories the loss of such an identity of fact and meaning is the root cause of the chaos which he envisions.

tig.atl: Vonnegut's Humor and the Limits of Hope

artinfo.ab: Kurt Vonnegut Jr. disavows the critical label 'black humorist,' and a closer reading of his published novels would seem to support his demur. The black humorist shows us the absurd conclusion of a course of action and invites us to laugh at the inevitable. Vonnegut steers us from an absurd course of action because he has something better in mind, although there is a marked inclination of his humorous imagination to dwell on the limitations of the possibilities that lie before us. His three most recent novels-+God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater= (1965), +Slaughterhouse-Five= (1969), and +Cat's Cradle= (1963)-level judgments at man and society analogous to those of his earlier works-+Player Piano) (1952), +Mother Night= (1961), and +The Sirens of Titan= (1959). The order within these triads is that of decreasing openness to the possibility of changing the human situation. Nevertheless, each of these novels offers us some alternative, however, slim, to the path of disaster that we seem consistently to prefer. There is hope, though, only if man respects the limits for truly humane contribution to his fellow man.

tig.atl: Hamartia in Death of a Salesman

artinfo.ab: A critic strives to show how the catastrophe of a drama is connected to the hamartia of its central character. In Miller's +Death of a Salesman= Willy Loman's hamartia is that his attempt to teach his sons has not been a failure but a success. He has taught them all he knows. The process has made not sexual but moral eunuchs of them. Nothing he does and nothing they do have any consequences. They cannot make anything happen. In the vulgate of the play one might say that they 'got no balls.' As he has emasculated himself, so he has emasculated them. Any man who does that to his own sons deserves whatever he gets. Willy's misery in life and death are decorus punishment for that act.

tig.atl: Clarissa's Attic: Virginia Woolf's Mrs. Dalloway Reconsidered

artinfo.ab: Virginia Woolf's +Mrs. Dalloway= is a study of complex individuals prevented from personal fulfillment by 'the sense of proportion' upheld by society. Examination of the text reveals the underlying traits that link Clarissa Dalloway to Septimus. Clarissa is in the foreground, whereas Septimus is a demonstration of what goes on behind the glittering front and the reasons for it. The exposition of Dr. Bradshaw constitutes an artistic flaw that mars the fine achievement of the novel in that he is burdened with symbolic import beyond what events portrayed warrant. On the surface Clarissa betrays a shallowness that when we learn her true nature-her lesbian bent-we realize is only assumed. To understand that we have to understand Septimus and grasp the corresponding points between his state and Clarissa's. The depth of Clarissa's character is extended for us through Septimus. Septimus' condition sends us out into the larger world and highlights its detrimental effects on the self-realization of non-conforming natures. Tolerance and freedom of the soul are the two principals for which Woolf pleads throughout +Mrs. Dalloway=.

tig.atl: Baudelaire and the Poetry of Robert Lowell

artinfo.ab: Lowell's debt to Baudelaire is apparent throughout Lowell's career, but it is especially great in four volumes. In +The Mills of the Kavanaughs=, "Mother Marie Therese" contains lines of unacknowledged translation from Baudelaire; these lines point the way to the calm, open style and humanistic sympathies of Lowell's later poetry. +Imitations=, which should be viewed as the author's spiritual diary rather than merely as an anthology of European poems, revolves around its group of Baudelaire "imitations" which function as Lowell's confession as well as Baudelaire's. Poems in +For the Union Dead= and +Near the Ocean=, such as "Eye and tooth," "For the Union Dead," "Waking Early Sunday Morning," and "Central Park," display Lowell's Baudelairean art at its best. In these poems, direct allusions to Baudelaire are less important than the overall parallels in tone, subject matter, and style.

tig.atl: Catch-23: The Mystery of Fact (Norman Mailer's Final Novel?)
Updike's Couples: Eros Demythologized
Expressionism and the New American Drama
Robert Creeley: A Checklist 1946-1970
Verdict-Guilty! A Study of The Trial
Alex in Wonderland, or Portnoy's Complaint
Quentin Compson: Self-Portrait of a Young Artist's Emotions
A William Golding Checklist
You've Come a Long Way, Babbitt! From Zenith to Ilium
A Time to Mourn and a Time to Dance: Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They?
Sartoris: Rereading the MacCallum Episode
The Questing Fear: Christian Allegory in John Updike's The Centaur
A Reading of Beckett's Imagination Dead Imagine
Modern Black African Writing in English: A Selected Bibliography
Love (and Marriage) in A Long and Happy Life
Faulkner's Mosquitoes: A Poetic Turning Point
The Realistic Structure of 'The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter'

artinfo.su: The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter (1940)

tig.atl: The Poetry of R. S. Thomas
Henry Roth's Call it Sleep: The Revival of a Proletarian Novel
Six Years of New World Writing: A Bibliographical Guide
A Harold Pinter Checklist

artinfo.ab: A working bibliography which in its first half attempts to list all of Pinter's work in all the forms in which it is available. This includes texts of his revue sketches, his poetry, and his editing efforts; recordings of his plays and revue sketches; and all available publications of his plays. The second half of the bibliography concerns itself with play reviews; critical works that either deal with Pinter as an entity or as a part of the absurd drama; and various interviews, news stories, and other biographical information. The entries are annotated as far as possible if they present any particular problem to the researcher.

tig.atl: The Poetry of W. S. Merwin

artinfo.ab: W. S. Merwin's poetic development can be accurately traced in five volumes of his published poems: +The Dancing Bears= (1954), +Green with Beasts= (1956), +The Drunk in the Furnace= (1960), +The Moving Target= (1963), and +The Lice= (1967). Disenchanted with the poetic traditions which he has inherited, he searches in his poetry for more appropriate fables and myths. His work follows a particular evolving pattern: from complex form to simple expression, from disillusion to renewed enthusiasm, and from personal anguish to an affirmation of the voyaging spirit.

tig.atl: Faulkner Draws the Long Bow

artinfo.ab: Most studies of Faulkner's debt to the frontier humorists do not adequately explore changes within the frontier tradition or within Faulkner's own works. The basic genre of old Southwest humor (the tall tale) has increased in formal and thematic complexity. Furthermore, that historical development is recapitulated in the sequence of Faulkner's comic writing. The tall tales in +Mosquitoes= (1927) are equivalent to the newspaper "yarns-in-print" of the 1820's; they mark Faulkner's apprenticeship in the frontier tradition. A second stage in his development as a humorist comes with the short stories of the 1930's. Here Faulkner's subjects, techniques, and language are those of the best writers of the old Southwest. Faulkner too has successfully converted an oral form into a distinctively literary one. In the Snopes trilogy and +The Reivers=, Faulkner expands that form into unified novels, an achievement even Mark Twain could not surpass. The comic irony of these works, far from indicating a break with frontier models, actually confirms their frontier nature. The unity of the Snopes trilogy derives from Ratliff's narrative voice, which derives, in turn, from the voice of the folk raconteur whose dead pan expression anticipates Ratliff's "faint constant humorous mask."

tig.atl: Edith Sitwell: Metaphysical Medium and Metaphysical Message
Getting Stuck: Joyce Cary's Gulley Jimson

artinfo.ab: Gulley Jimson, narrator-protagonist of Joyce Cary's +The Horse's Mouth=, accuses society of blocking his artistic endeavors, but actually provides his own motivational blocks. While he speaks of being progressive and for change, he remains tied to the security of the past. His obsession with Sara Monday and the sketches of her symbolizes this dependence. In three stages, marked by the three paintings which provide the structural form of the novel, he breaks his dependence. He stops "getting stuck" artistically and psychologically when he finds the courage to discard the security of his old dependencies and to commit himself to change, to living in the present.

tig.atl: A Brief Annotated Bibliography of Available Titles in Canadian Fiction, Poetry, and Related Background Material
Education in the Tribal/Global Village
Three New Canadian Plays

artinfo.ab: Drama has never been important in Canada, but three recently published and performed plays are of interest. +Crabdance= (1969), by Beverley Simons, is difficult and artificial, a comic treatment of salesmen in our society which also aims at the essence of the relationship between an aging woman and her husband, lover, and son. +The Ecstasy of Rita Joe= (performed 1967, published 1970), by George Ryga, is a poetic and urgent study of the problems of Indians in cities. +Colours in the Dark= (performed 1967, published 1969), by James Reaney, is also a poet's work, fragments of autobiography generalized to include biblical episodes and Canadian history. All three plays are unconventional, with Reaney's the most distinctively Canadian.

tig.atl: The Mind's Eyes (I's) (Ice): The Poetry of Margaret Avison
Modern Canadian Poetry

artinfo.ab: What is modern in poetry we would connect with aspects of radicalism in its style and attitude. What, in fact, we appear to be left with, as a sort of national residue, is that which seems impossible to reconcile with radicalism in our poetry: its nostalgia, its longing for history, its impulse to define a Canadian past and to create a usable tradition. The Canadian poet tends to focus on places remote from the poet's natural environs. Occasionally the image of a journey or of distance reflects the perception of those for whom emptiness has for too long been a burden. For the Canadian poet the problem is how to handle time and space. Time (history) comes to be handled through a vision of the primitive. Space finally comes to be occupied not by legend but by objects. And at this point, the terror of emptiness recedes. The spiritual project of humanizing the wilderness and of creating a usable past paradoxically turns itself inside out. It reaches completeness with its realization of the object and its acceptance of what is there.

tig.atl: The Modern French-Canadian Novel

artinfo.ab: The modern French-Canadian novel is of quite recent origin. The older novels, such as Louis Hémon's +Maria Chapdelaine= (1914) and Georges Bugnet's +La Forêt= (1935), describe the +habitant='s stoic character and his attachment to his land, his family, and his church. Ringuet's +Trente arpents= (1938), in which an old farmer is moved off his land to an ugly city, is a transition between earlier works, which deal with life close to nature, and post-1940 novels, concerned largely with life in large industrial centers, such as Gabrielle Roy's +Bonheur d'occasion= (1945), Roger Lemelin's +Au pied de la pente douce= (1944), André Langevin's +Poussière sur la ville= (1953), and Yves Thériault's +Aaron= (1954). Among the more important younger writers are Marie-Claire Blais, Jacques Godbout, Diane Giguère, and Bertrand Vac.

tig.atl: The American Adam and the Canadian Christ

artinfo.ab: Taken as a literary pattern, the redemptive figure of Christ is a helpful, unifying thread through a great diversity of Canadian novels. The development of such a figure as typical and symbolic in Canadian fiction is attributed to the fact that Canadian authors, like nineteenth-century American novelists, are writing in a context which lacks established gesture or manner, a definite social surface responsive to their touch. Possibly as a result of this, Canadian novels tend to be domestic rather than public, to present man in a confessional attitude rather than in his masks or social personae. Canadian novelists have worked their literary symbols harder at levels beyond the descriptive, creating images for the Canadian experience, many of them formed around "intensified figures of life." In American literature, the American Adam developed as the typical literary expression of a national experience; in Canada the corresponding archetype has been Christ. The appearance of the central redemptive figure is traced in the following novels: Hugh Maclennan's +The Watch That Ends the Night=; Morley Callaghan's +The Loved and the Lost= and +Such Is My Beloved=; Mordecai Richler's +The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz=; Malcolm Lowry's +Under the Volcano=; Leonard Cohen's +Beautiful Losers=; Sheila Watson's +The Double Hook=; and Robert Kroetsch's +The Words of My Roaring=.

tig.atl: Modern Canadian Literature
Albee: A Rare Balance

artinfo.ab: Albee's +A Delicate Balance= deserves more attention as both a well-balanced use of Albee's talents and a major accomplishment in contemporary serious drama. It appears to be underrated, as reflected in reviewers' tendency to dismiss the play as insufficiently "believable" or on grounds of personal impatience with Albee-critical criteria which are extraneous to the play as it stands. Fruitful reexamination of +A Delicate Balance= centers on an understanding of its special level of illusion, style, characterization, and theme. For all its lack of drawing-room realism, for example, the play is a finely crafted piece of supra-realism, of poetized reality (as exemplified in the precision and selection of language). Thus it is irrelevant to fully explain the curious situation of Harry and Edna or know all about the background of Tobias and family. The characters are less than specific, free to act out the central gesture of the theme: love me, protect me, what's left for me? Most elements of the play have metaphorical justification. Courageously for our time, +A Delicate Balance= is very talky; yet the talk does connote an action of ideas and insights. The characters' "terror" is time passing, time lost. We might even consider that the play has the shape of poetry. It is the best expression of the peculiar loneliness of our time that we have had in years-a quiet and un-paraded vision of Albee's honestly felt observations.

tig.atl: Steinbeck's Post-War Trilogy: A Return to Nature and the Natural Man

artinfo.ab: +Cannery Row= (1945), +The Wayward Bus= (1947), and +The Pearl= (1947) form a trilogy in which Steinbeck analyzes the intricate relationships between man and nature. In +Cannery Row=, Steinbeck creates characters (Doc, Mack, and the boys) who seek to live the benign natural life and are gloriously happy as they collect marine invertebrates in tide pools and catch frogs near the Carmel River. But the Row is an island surrounded by an expanding materialistic society which will ultimately destroy Doc and his friends. In +The Wayward Bus=, Steinbeck analyzes representative figures of this new order. Fusing the Flood motif with the Everyman allegory, Steinbeck rescues the modern American from his materialism by using nature to drive him to repent. Unfortunately, Steinbeck's portrayal of nature is overly schematic and the plot is not believable. In +The Pearl=, Steinbeck uses nature to prevent the natural man from becoming unnatural. By discarding his pearl after an angry nature seemingly drives him to renounce wealth, Kino chooses the natural life over material possessions. While not great novels when compared to +The Grapes of Wrath=, these books are among the best examples of Steinbeck's feeling for nature and affection for the natural man.

tig.atl: The Poet as Dog in Paterson

artinfo.ab: The image of the dog, a key image in the poem, is important both as a unifying device and as a figure for the artistic theme of +Paterson=. The choice of the dog image as an index to the poem is not an arbitrary one. Although +Paterson= is not overrun with dogs, dogs do manage to be about at important junctures in the poem. Williams first uses the dog image in the preface to Book I. What is suggested is a kind of Poundian periplum as the dog-poet haphazardly tries to know his world and find the beauty in it. In Book II the dog, Chichi, is related to two major themes in +Paterson=: the repression of the university and "love's deceit." Much of section ii in Book II is devoted to the theme of esthetic blockage. The dog imagery supports this blockage theme. In Book III the dog functions again as the symbol of the artist. In section iii the dead dog of the past floats downstream in the flood which helps to prepare the land for a new beginning. The dog symbolizes the artist's contention that the stagnating past must be destroyed before invention can take place. At the end of Book IV the poet seems worn out. He realizes his poem has not really been written. He has failed and the world has not been receptive. Williams closes Book IV with the image of a dog, a "large, compact bitch." The dogs in +Paterson= have their prime importance as figurations of the poet, as part of a developing pattern of esthetic doctrine. The dogs represent the frustration of the poet in his relation with his audience and language, the necessity of transformation and rebirth; and finally in Book V Williams' poetic credo is externalized in the tapestry passages at the end of the poem.

tig.atl: Tietjens' Travels: Parade's End as Comedy

artinfo.ab: +Parade's End= reveals many of the characteristics of comedy discussed by Northrop Frye. The novel is not only funny in incident, it is comic in overall structure. The passing of "parade" is, to a certain extent, regretted, but also it is celebrated in the comic exploding of the artificial Victorian-Edwardian society of McMaster and Campion. Sylvia is a victim of the old way (and Tietjens has alliances with this old way which implicate him in her suffering), but her presence does not detract from the comedy as a whole. The action of the story frees Tietjens from that part of himself which is restrictive and repressive. For him, the upper mind must always control the lower; it has always been the head over the heart. The war comes as the necessary end of the policy of repression and moral duplicity of the Victorians and Edwardians. As a result of the war, Tietjens is wounded in the head and eventually discovers the values of the body. The forces of Eros win, as usual in comedy, and Tietjens is free to move from the old world into the new. +Parade's End= presents a vision of what the world could be and, by engaging us in the action, moves toward the establishment of that world. The consideration of structure reveals how Ford, who said that the novelist should be "without views," could write a novel "that should have for its purpose the obviating of all future wars."

tig.atl: An Annotated Checklist of the Works of W. H. Auden
W. H. Auden: Annotated Checklist II (1958-1969)
What Price Arthur Miller? An Analysis of The Price

artinfo.ab: +The Price= represents an advance in Miller's work as he perceives the metaphysical foundation of social and psychological problems. It also indicates a growing existential element in his plays as he concedes a freedom of action to the individual not always apparent in his earlier work. Absurdity, in this play, is not an aspect of human nature but evidence of the nerveless and deluded nature of individuals determined to evade the responsibility of their freedom. In American terms, it is rooted in a perversion of the puritan ethic-in a commitment to money and ambition before compassion and concern. In +The Price= we are presented with several characters who are made suddenly aware of their direct responsibility for actions taken in the name of necessity and of the cost of embracing illusions in preference to reality. It seems clear that this play could only have been written following the laying of so many personal ghosts in +After the Fall=; yet, like that earlier work, +The Price= can perhaps be regarded as having a persuasive relevance to his own situation as he debates with himself the cost, in personal terms, of fame and ambition and the paramount need for human contact.

tig.atl: English Writing in Free India (1947-1967)

artinfo.ab: English writing in India since independence has grown in sophistication in dealing critically with Indian life and thought. The tradition of English writing in India goes back to the impact of colonial British rule on the educational system and on Indian society. The dominant genre up to World War I was romantic poetry colored by oriental mysticism (Tagore). Afterwards poetry and mysticism were ousted by prose realistic fiction which held the field between the two wars notably in Mulk Raj Anand's Marxist-orientated social realism. Independence therefore had a liberating effect on writers who had found nationalist politics obsessive or inhibiting and who could now treat Indian themes more personally. R. K. Narayan continued a cycle of comic novels about his invented South Indian town (Malgudi) abounding in eccentricity, with a new emphasis on the destructive effects of modernization. Raja Rao attempted a philosophical novel about the "Indian mystique" and R. P. Jhabvala wrote ironically of the struggle for power among the +nouveaux riches= of present-day Delhi. Khushwant Singh and other young writers have recently turned a fresh eye on such painful themes as the communal massacres which followed the partition and the tragic aspects of the nationalist struggle and the Second World War. There has been, however, reluctance to experiment formally or linguistically.
